class MainWindow(kivy.uix.boxlayout.BoxLayout): 
1058class MainWindow(BoxLayout):
1059    """
1060    Main window class which is the main window of the application
1061    """
1062
1063    def __init__(self, **kwargs):
1064        """
1065        The constructor for the MainWindow class which is the application,
1066        """
1067        super().__init__(**kwargs)
1068        # variables to do with the program
1069        self.zmk_config: ZMK.Config.ZMKConfig = ZMK.Config.ZMKConfig()
1070        """ZMK config object which stores handles the ZMK config"""
1071        self.json_file_path = ""
1072        """Variable is used to store the path to the json file which contains the keyboard layout editor data"""
1073        self.kle_json: pykle.Keyboard | None = None
1074        """Variable is used to store the parsed kle data from the json file with the pykle library"""
1075        # parameters to do with the widget/ gui
1076        self.orientation = "vertical"
1077        self.spacing = std.STD_SPACING
1078
1079        # Code to add the option bar
1080        # ========================================
1081        # initialize the option bar
1082        widget = BoxLayout(
1083            orientation="horizontal",
1084            spacing=std.STD_SPACING,
1085            size_hint_y=None,
1086            height=std.STD_BUTTON_HEIGHT
1087        )
1088        self.add_widget(widget)
1089        self.ids["option bar"] = widget
1090
1091        # ====================
1092        # test button
1093        widget = Button(
1094            text="Test",
1095            size_hint_x=None,
1096            width=metrics.sp(60),
1097            font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE,
1098            on_press=self.on_test_button
1099        )
1100        self.ids["option bar"].add_widget(widget)
1101        self.ids["option bar"].ids["test button"] = widget
1102
1103        # ====================
1104        # settings button
1105        widget = Button(
1106            text="Settings",
1107            size_hint_x=None,
1108            width=metrics.sp(80),
1109            font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE,
1110            on_press=self.on_settings_button
1111        )
1112        self.ids["option bar"].add_widget(widget)
1113        self.ids["option bar"].ids["settings button"] = widget
1114
1115        # ====================
1116        # load/save dropdown
1117        self.load_save_dropdown = DropDown()
1118        # creates the option buttons
1119        for option in ("New Config", "Load Config", "Save Config", "Save Config As"):
1120            button = Button(text=option, size_hint_y=None, height=std.STD_BUTTON_HEIGHT)
1121            # using a list with two functions which are called because they have () at the end
1122            # I did this because I did not want to create a new method for, I think it is more readable this way
1123            button.bind(on_release=lambda lambda_button: [
1124                # first function calls the method to close the dropdown
1125                self.load_save_dropdown.select(lambda_button.text),
1126                # second function calls the method in the class to handle that action
1127                # this dictionary acts as a switch statement
1128                {
1129                    "New Config"    : self.on_new_config,
1130                    "Load Config"   : self.on_load_config,
1131                    "Save Config"   : self.on_save_config,
1132                    "Save Config As": self.on_save_config_as
1133                }[lambda_button.text]()
1134            ])
1135            # add button to dropdown
1136            self.load_save_dropdown.add_widget(button)
1137
1138        # add the load/save button
1139        self.ids["option bar"].add_widget(Button(
1140            text="Load/Save",
1141            size_hint_x=None,
1142            width=metrics.sp(120),
1143            font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE,
1144            on_release=self.load_save_dropdown.open
1145        ))
1146
1147        # ====================
1148        # program status bar
1149        widget = Label(
1150            text=f"",
1151            markup=True,
1152            font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE,
1153            halign="left",
1154            valign="center",
1155            padding_x=std.STD_SPACING * 4,
1156        )
1157        self.ids["option bar"].add_widget(widget)
1158        self.ids["option bar"].ids["program status"] = widget
1159        widget.bind(size=widget.setter("text_size"))
1160        # ====================
1161        # console button
1162        widget = Button(
1163            text="Console",
1164            size_hint_x=None,
1165            width=metrics.sp(120),
1166            font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE,
1167            halign="left",
1168            valign="center",
1169            on_press=self.on_console_button
1170        )
1171        self.ids["option bar"].add_widget(widget)
1172        self.ids["option bar"].ids["console button"] = widget
1173
1174        # ========================================
1175        # navigation bar and screen manager
1176        # add the screen manager
1177
1178        # initialize the navigation bar
1179        widget = BoxLayout(
1180            orientation="horizontal",
1181            spacing=std.STD_SPACING,
1182            size_hint_y=None,
1183            height=std.STD_BUTTON_HEIGHT * 1.4
1184        )
1185        self.add_widget(widget)
1186        self.ids["navigation bar"] = widget
1187
1188        # this makes it easier to access the children of the screen manager
1189        # as otherwise you would have quite a nest of widgets
1190        self.screen_manager = ScreenManager(transition=NoTransition())
1191        self.add_widget(self.screen_manager)
1192        self.screen_names = {
1193            "MCU Selection": MCUSelectionScreen,
1194            "Properties"   : PropertiesScreen,
1195            "Row & Column" : RowColumnScreen,
1196            "GPIO"         : GpioScreen,
1197            "Keymap"       : KeymapScreen,
1198            "Export"       : ExportScreen,
1199            "Settings"     : SettingsScreen,
1200            "Console"      : ConsoleScreen
1201        }
1202        accessible_screen_names = ("Properties", "Row & Column", "GPIO", "Keymap", "Export")
1203        # adds the buttons for the different screens to the navigation bar
1204        # as well as the screen to the screen manager
1205        for screen_name in self.screen_names:
1206            # adds buttons for screen names that I want to be accessible in the navigation bar
1207            if screen_name in accessible_screen_names:
1208                button = Button(
1209                    text=screen_name,
1210                    font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE * 1.4,
1211                    on_release=self.on_nav_button
1212                )
1213                self.ids["navigation bar"].add_widget(button)
1214                self.ids["navigation bar"].ids[f"{screen_name} button"] = button
1215            # adds the screen to the screen manager
1216            self.screen_manager.add_widget(self.screen_names[screen_name](name=screen_name))
1217            self.screen_manager.current = screen_name
1218        self.screen_manager.current = "Properties"
1219
1220        # after everything has been added and initialized, the program status is updated
1221        # this is also done here since if it was done at the top when
1222        self.update_console("Program started")
1223
1224    def redraw_keymap(self):
1225        """
1226        This method is called when the keymap is changed and needs to be redrawn
1227        """
1228        row_column_screen: RowColumnScreen = self.screen_manager.get_screen("Row & Column")
1229        row_column_screen.redraw_keymap()
1230        key_map_screen: KeymapScreen = self.screen_manager.get_screen("Keymap")
1231        key_map_screen.redraw_keymap()
1232
1233    def on_nav_button(self, instance: Button):
1234        """
1235        This method is called when a navigation button is pressed. The method will change the screen to the screen that
1236        is associated with the button.
1237
1238        @param instance: required parameter for kivy
1239        """
1240        self.screen_manager.current = instance.text
1241
1242    # noinspection PyUnusedLocal
1243    def on_test_button(self, instance):
1244        """
1245        This method is called when the test button is pressed. The test button is just used for testing and is not part
1246        of the application
1247
1248        @param instance: required parameter for kivy
1249        """
1250        transform: ZMK.Transform.MatrixTransform = self.zmk_config.get_transform()
1251        print_debug(f"Transform matrix: {transform.get_matrix()}", info="Test Button")
1252        self.redraw_keymap()
1253
1254    # noinspection PyUnusedLocal
1255    def on_settings_button(self, instance):
1256        """
1257        This method is called when the settings button is pressed. The settings button will open the settings Screen
1258
1259        @param instance: required parameter for kivy
1260        """
1261        self.screen_manager.current = "Settings"
1262
1263    # noinspection PyUnusedLocal
1264    def on_console_button(self, instance):
1265        """
1266        This method is called when the console button is pressed. The console button will open the console Screen
1267
1268        @param instance: required parameter for kivy
1269        """
1270        self.screen_manager.current = "Console"

1274        """
1275        Method is called when the user wants to create a new configuration, not yet implemented
1276        """
1277        print_debug("New Config button pressed")

1300    def zmk_error(self, error: str | Exception):
1301        """
1302        The ZMK Package was created so that it could be used in other applications. Therefore, it is possible that
1303        the ZMK Package throw errors (purposefully), this program catches those errors and will display the error
1304        to the user at the top of the window as log it in the internal console. And revert the changes that caused the
1305        error.
1306
1307        @param error: either a string or an exception, if it is an exception, the name of the exception will be added to
1308        the string
1309        """
1310
1311        if isinstance(error, Exception):
1312            error = error.__class__.__name__ + ": " + str(error)
1313            print_debug(f"{error.__class__.__name__}, {error}", info="ZMK Error")
1314        else:
1315            print_debug(error, info="ZMK Error")
1316        self.update_console("ZMK Error: " + error)
1317
1318    def update_console(self, console_str: str):
1319        """
1320        Main method to be called to update the console, it updates the console and the program status
1321        """
1322        console_screen: ConsoleScreen = self.screen_manager.get_screen("Console")
1323        console_screen.update_console(console_str)
1324        self.ids["option bar"].ids["program status"].text = f"[b]Program Status:[/b] [i]{console_str}[/i]"
1325
1326    @staticmethod
1327    def event_callback(widget_id: str = "", **kwargs):
1328        """
1329        Method is called by the children held within the layout of the screens within the screen manager, this is a
1330        callback method which is called when the user changes a value in the configuration
1331
1332        @param widget_id: key is id of the widget which has changed
1333        @param kwargs: a dictionary is used for potential arguments for methods that this method will call
1334        """
1335        # this method is deprecated
1336        print_debug(f"widget_id: {widget_id}, kwargs: {kwargs}", info="Event Callback")

1077        self.spacing = std.STD_SPACING
1078
1079        # Code to add the option bar
1080        # ========================================
1081        # initialize the option bar
1082        widget = BoxLayout(
1083            orientation="horizontal",
1084            spacing=std.STD_SPACING,
1085            size_hint_y=None,
1086            height=std.STD_BUTTON_HEIGHT
1087        )
1088        self.add_widget(widget)
1089        self.ids["option bar"] = widget
1090
1091        # ====================
1092        # test button
1093        widget = Button(
1094            text="Test",
1095            size_hint_x=None,
1096            width=metrics.sp(60),
1097            font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE,
1098            on_press=self.on_test_button
1099        )
1100        self.ids["option bar"].add_widget(widget)
1101        self.ids["option bar"].ids["test button"] = widget
1102
1103        # ====================
1104        # settings button
1105        widget = Button(
1106            text="Settings",
1107            size_hint_x=None,
1108            width=metrics.sp(80),
1109            font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE,
1110            on_press=self.on_settings_button
1111        )
1112        self.ids["option bar"].add_widget(widget)
1113        self.ids["option bar"].ids["settings button"] = widget
1114
1115        # ====================
1116        # load/save dropdown
1117        self.load_save_dropdown = DropDown()
1118        # creates the option buttons
1119        for option in ("New Config", "Load Config", "Save Config", "Save Config As"):
1120            button = Button(text=option, size_hint_y=None, height=std.STD_BUTTON_HEIGHT)
1121            # using a list with two functions which are called because they have () at the end
1122            # I did this because I did not want to create a new method for, I think it is more readable this way
1123            button.bind(on_release=lambda lambda_button: [
1124                # first function calls the method to close the dropdown
1125                self.load_save_dropdown.select(lambda_button.text),
1126                # second function calls the method in the class to handle that action
1127                # this dictionary acts as a switch statement
1128                {
1129                    "New Config"    : self.on_new_config,
1130                    "Load Config"   : self.on_load_config,
1131                    "Save Config"   : self.on_save_config,
1132                    "Save Config As": self.on_save_config_as
1133                }[lambda_button.text]()
1134            ])
1135            # add button to dropdown
1136            self.load_save_dropdown.add_widget(button)
1137
1138        # add the load/save button
1139        self.ids["option bar"].add_widget(Button(
1140            text="Load/Save",
1141            size_hint_x=None,
1142            width=metrics.sp(120),
1143            font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE,
1144            on_release=self.load_save_dropdown.open
1145        ))
1146
1147        # ====================
1148        # program status bar
1149        widget = Label(
1150            text=f"",
1151            markup=True,
1152            font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE,
1153            halign="left",
1154            valign="center",
1155            padding_x=std.STD_SPACING * 4,
1156        )
1157        self.ids["option bar"].add_widget(widget)
1158        self.ids["option bar"].ids["program status"] = widget
1159        widget.bind(size=widget.setter("text_size"))
1160        # ====================
1161        # console button
1162        widget = Button(
1163            text="Console",
1164            size_hint_x=None,
1165            width=metrics.sp(120),
1166            font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE,
1167            halign="left",
1168            valign="center",
1169            on_press=self.on_console_button
1170        )
1171        self.ids["option bar"].add_widget(widget)
1172        self.ids["option bar"].ids["console button"] = widget
1173
1174        # ========================================
1175        # navigation bar and screen manager
1176        # add the screen manager
1177
1178        # initialize the navigation bar
1179        widget = BoxLayout(
1180            orientation="horizontal",
1181            spacing=std.STD_SPACING,
1182            size_hint_y=None,
1183            height=std.STD_BUTTON_HEIGHT * 1.4
1184        )
1185        self.add_widget(widget)
1186        self.ids["navigation bar"] = widget
1187
1188        # this makes it easier to access the children of the screen manager
1189        # as otherwise you would have quite a nest of widgets
1190        self.screen_manager = ScreenManager(transition=NoTransition())
1191        self.add_widget(self.screen_manager)
1192        self.screen_names = {
1193            "MCU Selection": MCUSelectionScreen,
1194            "Properties"   : PropertiesScreen,
1195            "Row & Column" : RowColumnScreen,
1196            "GPIO"         : GpioScreen,
1197            "Keymap"       : KeymapScreen,
1198            "Export"       : ExportScreen,
1199            "Settings"     : SettingsScreen,
1200            "Console"      : ConsoleScreen
1201        }
1202        accessible_screen_names = ("Properties", "Row & Column", "GPIO", "Keymap", "Export")
1203        # adds the buttons for the different screens to the navigation bar
1204        # as well as the screen to the screen manager
1205        for screen_name in self.screen_names:
1206            # adds buttons for screen names that I want to be accessible in the navigation bar
1207            if screen_name in accessible_screen_names:
1208                button = Button(
1209                    text=screen_name,
1210                    font_size=std.STD_FONT_SIZE * 1.4,
1211                    on_release=self.on_nav_button
1212                )
1213                self.ids["navigation bar"].add_widget(button)
1214                self.ids["navigation bar"].ids[f"{screen_name} button"] = button
1215            # adds the screen to the screen manager
1216            self.screen_manager.add_widget(self.screen_names[screen_name](name=screen_name))
1217            self.screen_manager.current = screen_name
1218        self.screen_manager.current = "Properties"
1219
1220        # after everything has been added and initialized, the program status is updated
1221        # this is also done here since if it was done at the top when
1222        self.update_console("Program started")

The constructor for the MainWindow class which is the application,

ZMK config object which stores handles the ZMK config

json_file_path

Variable is used to store the path to the json file which contains the keyboard layout editor data

kle_json: pykle_serial.serial.Keyboard | None

Variable is used to store the parsed kle data from the json file with the pykle library

orientation

Orientation of the layout.

orientation is an ~kivy.properties.OptionProperty and defaults to 'horizontal'. Can be 'vertical' or 'horizontal'.

spacing

Spacing between children, in pixels.

spacing is a ~kivy.properties.NumericProperty and defaults to 0.

def zmk_error(self, error: str | Exception): 
1300    def zmk_error(self, error: str | Exception):
1301        """
1302        The ZMK Package was created so that it could be used in other applications. Therefore, it is possible that
1303        the ZMK Package throw errors (purposefully), this program catches those errors and will display the error
1304        to the user at the top of the window as log it in the internal console. And revert the changes that caused the
1305        error.
1306
1307        @param error: either a string or an exception, if it is an exception, the name of the exception will be added to
1308        the string
1309        """
1310
1311        if isinstance(error, Exception):
1312            error = error.__class__.__name__ + ": " + str(error)
1313            print_debug(f"{error.__class__.__name__}, {error}", info="ZMK Error")
1314        else:
1315            print_debug(error, info="ZMK Error")
1316        self.update_console("ZMK Error: " + error)

The ZMK Package was created so that it could be used in other applications. Therefore, it is possible that the ZMK Package throw errors (purposefully), this program catches those errors and will display the error to the user at the top of the window as log it in the internal console. And revert the changes that caused the error.

@param error: either a string or an exception, if it is an exception, the name of the exception will be added to the string

title

Title of your application. You can set this as follows::

class MyApp(App):
    def build(self):
        self.title = 'Hello world'

New in version 1.0.5.

Changed in version 1.8.0: title is now a ~kivy.properties.StringProperty. Don't set the title in the class as previously stated in the documentation.

For Kivy < 1.8.0, you can set this as follows::

class MyApp(App):
    title = 'Custom title'

If you want to dynamically change the title, you can do::

from kivy.base import EventLoop
EventLoop.window.title = 'New title'
icon

Icon of your application. The icon can be located in the same directory as your main file. You can set this as follows::

class MyApp(App):
    def build(self):
        self.icon = 'myicon.png'

New in version 1.0.5.

Changed in version 1.8.0: icon is now a ~kivy.properties.StringProperty. Don't set the icon in the class as previously stated in the documentation.

For Kivy prior to 1.8.0, you need to set this as follows::

class MyApp(App):
    icon = 'customicon.png'

Recommended 256x256 or 1024x1024? for GNU/Linux and Mac OSX 32x32 for Windows7 or less. <= 256x256 for windows 8 256x256 does work (on Windows 8 at least), but is scaled down and doesn't look as good as a 32x32 icon.
